result.execSummary:
The defendant Sancho F. Ellis was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess w/Intent-Heroin (<=3g), a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(d)1.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: GFE to obtain/maintain FTE/FT schooling or combination thereof.

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  

A copy of the police report has been electronically sent to the probation office.

Any assessment/treatment/counseling deemed appropriate by PO including AODA and any follow up recommened.

Deft may transfer probation to North Carolina.

timeConds.notes: with credit for 324 days of time already served, to be applied to the conditional jail (jail time is considered completed).

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Sancho F. Ellis

records.addlTxt: Discharged 04.23.2021
w/Notice of Right to Seek Postconviction Relief

Clerk Cheree
Case called: 2:17pm
State appears by ADA K.Puig.  Def appears in person and with Atty Peter Rotter.  
Plea Quest/Waiver of Rights filed.  VR not applicable.

State moves to:
Cts. 1 and 2>> (both Possess w/Intent-Cocaine >15-40g)>>D&RI
COURT GRANTS ABOVE.

PLEA:
Ct. 3 (Possess w/Intent - Heroin <=3g)>> NO CONTEST

COURT advises def of rights (including constitutional rights) & penalties & ques def to understanding.  
COURT finds plea & waiver of rights freely & vol made, a factual basis & def guilty.

COURT ORDERS: Sentence W/held; 3 years Probation.
CONDITIONS>> 10 months MCJ w/credit for 324 days of time already served, to be applied to the conditional jail (jail time is considered completed); Any assessment/treatment/counseling deemed appropriate by PO including AODA and any follow up recommended; Absolute sobriety; GFE to obtain/maintain FTE/FT schooling or combination thereof; DNA sample (already provided) and surcharge; CC.

>> Defendant may transfer probation to North Carolina.

Case called:  9:06 am  
Clerk:  Kim H.
14CF804

State appears ADA Kyle Mayo.  Defendant appears in custody and with Atty Peter Rotter.  Date and time set for Motion Hearing.  Court notes he does not have time for Motion to Suppress today.  Motion to Suppress rescheduled to June 8, 2015 at 9:00 am.  COURT reviews motions filed.  Parties agree Court has all motions necessary for next hearing.  COURT questions Atty Rotter regarding portions of CD to review.  Atty Rotter refers to the supplemental filed 4/16 and 3/5 for what he thinks is relevant on video.  COURT asks Atty Rotter to submit by Friday a list of what is necessary to review.  Atty Rotter states he will provide list by Friday.  COURT addresses bond modification.  Atty Rotter request Court modify to signature bond w/electronic monitor.  ADA Mayo objects to modification and makes argument.  COURT questions defendant's missed appearances.  ADA Mayo states he absconded from DOC-probation hold.  COURT amends to $75,000.00 signature bond with first $25,000.00 cash w/same conditions.
